newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle trade thin at $69-feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle trade thin at $69-feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle Thursday sold at $69.00 per cwt in light volume, unchanged from brisk sales on Tuesday, feedlot sources said.
About 6,500 head sold in Kansas, which brought the week to date figure to 94,000, they said.
An estimated 5,000 head sold in the Texas Panhandle and western Oklahoma area, which brought the weekly movement near 86,000, sources said.
Most of this week's showlists reportedly were almost sold out amid strong demand from packers stocking live inventories to meet a flurry of retail beef orders, they said.
Retail beef demand was fueled by a push for orders ahead of the Memorial Day holiday weekend, which traditionally kicks off the summer outdoor grilling season, market sources said.
The three-day Memorial Day weekend has a reputation as the most active weekend of the year for beef consumption, they said.
However, beef prices slipped for a second consecutive day, with weakness tied to heavy cattle slaughter this week and belief that retail demand was peaking, the sources said.
Beef prices were quoted down $0.24 to $0.69 per cwt, with 240 fabricated beef loads sold, USDA reported.

Heavyweight choice beef was down $0.44 at $107.07, down $1.51 since prices started falling on Tuesday, USDA statistics showed. Fabricated beef sales for the week totaled 961 loads, down 10.4 percent from the same period last week at 1,072.
